urn:contentItem:5XKW-HPX1-JD34-V1KY-00000-00Helicopters arrive for bushfire season2019-11-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisHelicopters arrive for bushfire season

TWO firefighting aircraft that arrived in Bendigo on Wednesday will be a welcome boost for regional fire crews.

The two Bendigo-based helicopters will be used by Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) and CFA to respond to fires across central Victoria.

"The helicopters are critical in stopping the spread of fire," FFMVic fire and emergency preparedness regional manager Carsten Nannestad said. "They often arrive at a fire quicker than ground crews, providing immediate response in the early stages and supporting firefighters on the ground."

Filling its water tank in 40 seconds with a three-metre snorkel, the Bell 214B water bombing helicopter is capable of carrying 2650 litres of water. Air Attack Supervisor, an Airbus EC120, will liase between ground and air fire crews, identify where water drops will be most effective and locate nearby water refill sites.

Both helicopters will be on standby every day throughout summer to respond to fires in central Victoria. They are part of a fleet of 50 firefighting aircraft in Victoria.

urn:contentItem:5VHF-HMT1-F0J6-J4YD-00000-00Candelo RFS men go to Victoria2019-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Candelo RFS men go to VictoriaAlbert McKnight

Two of the Candelo Rural Fire Service's youngest members went to Victoria for six days last week to help their southern neighbours. It was the second major deployment for Jack Matthews, 21, and Matt Jennings, 20, who have been part of the Candelo team since they were in their early teens. They assisted the Country Fire Authority and Forest Fire Management Victoria outside Buchan, north of Orbost, controlling and putting out hotspots around backburning that is taking place to stop a bushfire that burnt over 21,000ha.

urn:contentItem:5P58-D541-F0J6-J0RH-00000-00Search begins for 350 firefighters ahead of summer | Video2017-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisSearch begins for 350 firefighters ahead of summer | Video

Forest Fire Management Victoria is searching for project firefighters to help tackle projects across the region as summer preparations begin.

Statewide 300 summer project firefighters are needed as well as 49 permanent operations officer roles.

Murray Goldfields district manager, Paul Bates, said advertising started this week for project firefighters and forest and fire operations officers in the Murray Goldfields district.

"All the roles will be based at Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning and Parks Victoria offices and depots in central Victoria," Mr Bates said.

"The project firefighter jobs will be located at Castlemaine, Inglewood, Cohuna, Echuca, Avoca, Bendigo, Heathcote, Maryborough, Rushworth and St Arnaud.

"The Forest Fire Operations Officer jobs will be based in Castlemaine and Cohuna.

"These frontline forest firefighters are an important addition to our resources as we prepare for the upcoming fire season in the Loddon Mallee region," Mr Bates said.

To find out more and apply, click here or call 136 186.

Video courtesy of the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning.

urn:contentItem:5WPY-61X1-JD34-V20H-00000-00Fine for sourcing illegal firewood2019-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisFine for sourcing illegal firewoodChris Pedler

A 22-year-old Lake Charm man has been fined for illegally cutting and collecting wood in the Guttrum State Forest, north of Kerang.

Forest Fire Management Victoria officers came upon the man during a regular trail bike forest patrol.

"It is illegal for people to collect firewood outside designated firewood collection seasons or to fall trees in state forests at any time of the year," FFMVic forest and fire operations officer Nick Whatley said.

"After speaking with the man, we issued him an infringement notice and seized the firewood. The firewood has been held as evidence pending any further legal proceedings."

Domestic firewood collection on public land is currently closed. The spring collection season will open on September 1.

Visit the Department of Land, Water and Planning website for more details.

urn:contentItem:5XHR-TW31-JD34-V0TR-00000-00Grass fire near Rochester under control2019-11-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisGrass fire near Rochester under controlTara Cosoleto

Update 12.50pm

A grass fire near Rochester is under control.

Update, 11.55am

The Country Fire Authority has issued an advice message for residents in Ballendella, Fairy Dell, Nanneella and Strathallan.

The CFA spokesperson said the grass fire at Burgoine Road, Strathallan is not yet under control and is travelling towards the river reserve.

There is currently no threat to residents.

The CFA is encouraging people to keep roads clear so emergency services can respond.

Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads.

At least 10 CFA crews and Forest Fire Management are responding to the fire.

Earlier

The Country Fire Authority is responding to a grass and scrub fire near Rochester.

Crews were called to the blaze on Burgoine Road, Strathallan about 11.19am.

The fire is not yet under control.

More to come.

urn:contentItem:5N89-RTJ1-JD34-V3FN-00000-00Grass and scrub fire contained at Toolondo2017-04-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisGrass and scrub fire contained at ToolondoRex Martinich

COUNTRY Fire Authority and Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters have contained a grass and scrub fire near Digger Jims Road at Toolondo, about 16 kilometres north east of Harrow.

The fire was reported just after 4pm on Thursday and was declared under control at about 6pm.

Firefighters are attending and will continue to patrol the fire for several hours.

The CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria have advised that the fire has burnt over 145 hectares including grassland and scrub.

"Large volumes of smoke may continue to seen from surrounding communities for several hours," an emergency advice message stated.

"There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions."

urn:contentItem:4632-GBV0-015G-X382-00000-00<published>2002-06-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:57:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FOREIGN; Pg. 24</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Angry wife blamed for forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">DENVER: A woman employed by the US Forest Service is suspected of starting one of the largest fires in Colorado history while on patrol to enforce fire bans.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Forestry technician Terry Barton, 38, was arrested on suspicion of starting the 40,000ha fire that threatened the homes of 45,000 residents and forced more than 5000 people to evacuate.</p><p>Police allege Ms Barton was looking for illegal fires on June 8 when she burnt a letter from her estranged husband in a campfire ring, despite a fire ban. She claimed she tried to put out the fire.</p><p> She is charged with setting fire to timber in a national forest and making false statements to investigators, and faces up to 10 years in jail and about $500,000 in fines if convicted.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5TMG-Y011-JD34-V1D0-00000-00Natimuk bushfire2018-11-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNatimuk bushfireJade Bate

A BUSHFIRE burned five hectares of bushland near Natimuk on Thursday morning.

Country Fire Authority District 17 operations officer Alfred Mason said volunteer crews received the call at 5.50am.

"For four hours they fought the blaze and managed to keep it contained that whole time. We requested supported from Forest Fire Management. They only left at 1.50pm," he said.

Mr Mason said the cause of the fire was not yet known.

urn:contentItem:5NBN-G4N1-F0J6-J381-00000-00Fuel reduction burns in Maryborough, Whipstick2017-04-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisFuel reduction burns in Maryborough, Whipstick

RELATED: Planned burns to be held this week

SMOKE might be visible in the vicinity of Maryborough and Whipstick from tomorrow, with fuel reduction burns planned.

Weather conditions permitting, Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority will be conducting burns in the Greater Bendigo National Park and the Craigie State Forest.

The Greater Bendigo National Park fuel reduction burn will encompass 779 hectares in the area of Brights Lane in Whipstick, 13 kilometres north of Bendigo.

The fuel reduction burn in the Craigie State Forest will be 359 hectares in size and will be in the vicinity of the Centenary Reservoir, 2.5 kilometres south of Maryborough.

The burns should be ignited on Wednesday and complete by Sunday.

Smoke might be visible from Huntly, Eaglehawk, Maiden Gully, Long Gully, Bendigo, Maryborough and Daisy Hill.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority have issued the following advice:

urn:contentItem:5TS4-GYG1-F0JP-W10W-00000-00Crews battle bushfire blaze2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Crews battle bushfire blazeOLIVIA REED

A WATER-BOMBING helicopter and 10 firefighting crews were trying to contain a 51-hectare bushfire at Carlisle River last night.

VicEmergency issued a watch and act warning for the Westwicks Rd fire, about 30km southwest of Colac, at 6.10pm yesterday.

"The bushfire is travelling in a south-easterly direction towards the Gellibrand River Road," VicEmergency said on its website. Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA crews were attending the fire.

urn:contentItem:5MXG-9HT1-F0JP-W2K5-00000-00Anger at ravers' partying2017-02-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Anger at ravers' partying

THE Department of Environment Land, Water and Planning could take action over an illegal rave party in the Wombat Forest near Bullengarook early this month.

Forest Fire Victoria's Grampians forest and fire regional manager Peter Kambouris last Wednesday urged anyone with information to come forward after crews had to clean up a large mess and put out a substantial fire left behind.

"Our attending Forest Fire Management Victoria crew found the fire pit was still alight, contained empty bottles, cans, small disco balls and even camp chairs," he said.

He said they also collected 11 bags of garbage and had to clean up surrounding bushland that had been used as a toilet.

Littering attracts fines of up to $6218 while leaving campfires unattended can cost offenders $15,546.Information to Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

urn:contentItem:5WPY-61X1-JD34-V24M-00000-00Fine for sourcing illegal firewood2019-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEFine for sourcing illegal firewoodChris Pedler

A 22-year-old Lake Charm man has been fined for illegally cutting and collecting wood in the Guttrum State Forest, north of Kerang.

Forest Fire Management Victoria officers came upon the man during a regular trail bike forest patrol.

"It is illegal for people to collect firewood outside designated firewood collection seasons or to fall trees in state forests at any time of the year," FFMVic forest and fire operations officer Nick Whatley said.

"After speaking with the man, we issued him an infringement notice and seized the firewood. The firewood has been held as evidence pending any further legal proceedings."

Domestic firewood collection on public land is currently closed. The spring collection season will open on September 1.

Visit the Department of Land, Water and Planning website for more details.

urn:contentItem:5M8K-DHV1-F0J6-J3M2-00000-00Planned burns scheduled2016-11-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisPlanned burns scheduled

THREE fuel reduction burns are scheduled to take place in the Bendigo area on Wednesday.

Depending on the weather, Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters hope to complete burns in Golden Square, Huntly and Kangaroo Flat.

The first will cover about 23 hectares in Golden Square at Specimen Hill Channel.

The planned burn in Kangaroo Flat will be along Irwin and Dorrington lanes, and at Huntly will take place on Viola Road.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Murray Goldfields district manager Paul Bates said asked community members to call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226, rather than Triple Zero, if they saw smoke and were concerned.

People experiencing symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.

urn:contentItem:5TTV-8X71-JD34-V11S-00000-00Planned burn to take place in Stawell2018-11-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisPlanned burn to take place in Stawell

Forest Fire Management Victoria will undertake a planned burn in Stawell between about 12pm and 6pm on Monday.

The burn will take place at Brook Farm Road, with the objective to develop a fuel reduced corridor to the north of Stawell.

The burn off will hope to reduce the speed and intensity of bushfires should one occur.

Residents have been urged to take care near the area, with visibility potentially reducing due to smoke associated with the burn.

urn:contentItem:5XM9-G1X1-F0J6-J14R-00000-00Spring firewood collection season wraps up on November 302019-11-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisSpring firewood collection season wraps up on November 30Chris Pedler

Today is the last day for spring firewood collection with serious penalties applying to people who break the law.

People face fines up to $8261 or one year in prison could for not following firewood collection rules.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's district manager for murray goldfields Adrian Parker said it is illegal for people to collect firewood on public land until the autumn firewood collection season opens in March next year.

"Serious penalties apply for those who break the law," he said. "Video surveillance cameras are used to monitor state forests and are complimented with regular patrols of forest areas.

"These officers can issue on-the-spot fines or take people to court for major offences.

"We want to remind the public that firewood can only be taken from designated collection areas in state forests during firewood collection season and is for personal use only and cannot be sold."

For details on firewood collection visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood To report illegal removal of firewood from public land phone DELWP on 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5XM9-G1X1-F0J6-J0TN-00000-00Spring firewood collection season wraps up on November 302019-11-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATESpring firewood collection season wraps up on November 30Chris Pedler

Today is the last day for spring firewood collection with serious penalties applying to people who break the law.

People face fines up to $8261 or one year in prison could for not following firewood collection rules.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's district manager for murray goldfields Adrian Parker said it is illegal for people to collect firewood on public land until the autumn firewood collection season opens in March next year.

"Serious penalties apply for those who break the law," he said. "Video surveillance cameras are used to monitor state forests and are complimented with regular patrols of forest areas.

"These officers can issue on-the-spot fines or take people to court for major offences.

"We want to remind the public that firewood can only be taken from designated collection areas in state forests during firewood collection season and is for personal use only and cannot be sold."

For details on firewood collection visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood To report illegal removal of firewood from public land phone DELWP on 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5V9P-CY41-JD34-V4P5-00000-00Car fire at Green Lake2019-01-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisCar fire at Green LakeAlexander Darling

Ambulance Victoria said there were no serious injuries resulting from a fire that started in a car at Green Lake on Wednesday afternoon.

CFA Regional Duty Officer Luke Patterson said they were called to a patch of land surrounding the Western Highway and Taylor's Road at 3:30pm, after the fire spread to surrounding grassland.

They needed under an hour to control it. "The CFA sent thirteen vehicles and two firefighting aircraft to the scene, while Forest Fire Management Victoria also headed out with a bulldozer to take care of nearby hazardous trees," Mr Patterson said.

urn:contentItem:5W3W-NK61-F0JP-W3W9-00000-00Planned burn for Aireys2019-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Planned burn for Aireys

AUTHORITIES will ignite a 1200-hectare planned burn at Airey's Inlet today. The planned burn is two kilometres west of Airey's Inlet towards Currawong Falls.

The Country Fire Authority and Forest Fire Management will monitor the burn before extinguishing it on May 20.

Speed restrictions will be enforced on Distillery Creek and Bambra roads for the duration of the planned burn operations and the Southern Distillery Creek Picnic ground and tracks will remain open to the public.

Distillery Creek North Picnic Ground, Ironbark Drive, Bird Hide Track, Ironbark Gorge Track, Nature Track, Currawong Falls Track, Loves Track and Batson Track will be closed until further notice.Authorities will use aircraft to ignite the burn, with the aim of reducing dry vegetation.

urn:contentItem:4M5M-6KX0-TWT8-W35R-00000-00Vic: Forest fire expected to be under control by tomorrow2006-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVic: Forest fire expected to be under control by tomorrowMELBOURNE Oct 21

  Fire crews expect to have a small fire in the Barmah State Forest in central Victoria under control by tomorrow.


   The Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) says the 2.5 hectare fire that sparked early today was contained about 2pm (AEST).
   DSE state duty officer Andrew Graystone said 15 DSE firefighters and 20 from the CFA were brought in to fight the blaze, supported by a helicopter.
   The crews built control lines around it and it was expected to be controlled by tomorrow, he said.
   "It's safe as far as we don't expect it to get any bigger," he said.
   The fire is believed to have been deliberately lit.

urn:contentItem:4N8J-0610-TWT9-238H-00000-00Vic: Firefighters build containment lines around forest fire2007-03-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVic: Firefighters build containment lines around forest fireMELBOURNE March 15

  Firefighters have built containment lines around a blaze that broke out in Victoria's Otway Ranges National Park today.


   The bushfire started at about 1.30pm (AEDT) near Gellibrand in the state's south-west and has blacked out 100 hectares.
   Residents were put on alert for smoke and falling embers earlier today as the temperature in the area hit the low 30s.
   More than 80 firefighters were on site, using aircraft bombers and bulldozers to stop the blaze spreading.
   Containment lines have been built around the fire and authorities expect it to be brought under control early tomorrow.
   The Country Fire Authority (CFA) said the flame height was tonight less than a metre, winds were low, humidity high and the fire was not expected to spread.
   "There'll be crews containing it in the night, there's no doubt about that - minimal crews, the weather's pretty benign down here at the moment," a CFA spokesman said.
   The cause of the fire is unknown.

urn:contentItem:5XJ2-GBK1-F0J6-J16K-00000-00Helping to fight the NSW bushfires2019-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisHelping to fight the NSW bushfires

Eight Forest Fire Management firefighters from the Loddon Mallee region have been deployed to NSW to help battle more than 70 bushfires raging across the state.

The eight firefighters will join a crew of 10 from the Grampians to create one full task force.

"This is the second task force from the Loddon Mallee that has been deployed to NSW in the past fortnight," acting regional manager for forest and fire operations Paul Bates said.

"They will provide immediate respite for crews that have already been fighting the fires for several weeks.

"This task force will be deployed for seven days and increase numbers of firefighters on the ground to share the workload, combat fatigue and keep the community and each other safe."

Another two staff will also head north to assist in the Incident Management Teams.

It comes after about 50 CFA firefighters from central Victoria joined the NSW crews on Monday. At least three people have died and 150 homes have been destroyed on the north coast of NSW in the past several days.

urn:contentItem:5XGG-0R01-F0J6-J508-00000-00Burns planned near Castlemaine2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisBurns planned near Castlemaine

A number of burns have been planned near Castlemaine in the next two days.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority will conduct two burns on Tuesday and Wednesday in the Walmer State Forest.

The first will be about three kilometres north-west of Castlemaine.

The other burn will be at Castlemaine-Barkers Creek, about four kilometres north of Castlemaine.

Read more: CFA crews manage smouldering Elmore hay shed fire

The burns should be completed sometime between 10am on Tuesday and 8pm on Friday.

Smoke could be visible from Castlemaine, Muckleford, and Barkers Creek until Friday.

The CFA is warning there could be low visibility on the roads due to smoke.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites near the burn areas could also be restricted.

Residents can find out more information about the burns at ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn

urn:contentItem:5V21-F3Y1-JD34-V1TK-00000-00Nearly 60 campfire call-outs in months for Hume2018-12-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Nearly 60 campfire call-outs in months for HumeEllen Ebsary

Since November, Forest Fire Management Victoria units in the Hume region have responded to 56 fires caused by campfires.

The agency is reminding campers to light their fires in a trench at least 30 centimetres deep and no larger than one square metre and to extinguish it fully.

Hume assistant chief fire officer Aaron Kennedy said 10 per cent of all bushfires were caused by campfires.

"When campfires escape, that could have been prevented by following a simple set of rules, it's very frustrating," he said.

urn:contentItem:5VBH-KPP1-F0JP-W1B8-00000-00Aircraft help end grassfire2019-02-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 25Aircraft help end grassfire

A GRASSFIRE that first started on Wednesday evening was brought under control late yesterday.

The Lake Connewarre fire began on Wednesday night, ignited by a lightning strike.

It reignited on Thursday morning, and crews from Forest Fire Management and the CFA worked to extinguish the blaze.

FFM operations manager David Roberts said the fire burned about 34 hectares. Between Wednesday and yesterday, about 85 firefighters worked on the blaze, he said.

Water-bombing aircraft were brought in on Wednesday and Thursday to fight the fire."We had a private property on the northern side that had some stock that needed to be relocated," Mr Roberts said.

urn:contentItem:5XMV-66B1-DY19-C1V8-00000-00Man dies fighting bushfires in East Gippsland2019-12-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisMan dies fighting bushfires in East GippslandPaul Sakkal

The 69-year-old's vehicle rolled down an embankment at a private property near Orbost.

A contractor helping firefighters in East Gippsland has died after the vehicle he was driving rolled down an embankment.

The 69-year-old was working on a private property in the suburb of Gelantipy, near Orbost.

#BREAKING: A contractor helping firefighters in Victoria has died.   #9News   pic.twitter.com/36ST30Blbz

??? Nine News Melbourne (@9NewsMelb) December 1, 2019

The contractor for the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning died at the scene.

Police have prepared a report for the coroner, who will investigate the death.

The state's workplace safety watchdog, WorkSafe, will also investigate the incident.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's chief fire officer Chris Hardman said his organisation would "cooperate fully with the investigation into this tragic incident."

"Tragically, a man working in support of our firefighter activities near Gelantipy died late Saturday."

"Our thoughts are with his family, friends and workmates."

Two advice warnings are in place for bushfires in East Gippsland.

Crews and aircraft are battling a blaze 6km east of Ensay, while another, 2km east of W Tree, is 10,800ha in size.

More to come.

A GROUP of seventeen Victorian emergency workers yesterday returned from a 37-day deployment to the US.

The Victorians were part of a 140-strong Australian and New Zealand contingent that answered an SOS from Northern California, where devastating bushfires blazed across more than 700,000 hectares.

The wildfires required almost 16,000 firefighters over 14 US states.Victorian Minister for Emergency Services James Merlino said the CFA and Forest Fire Management personnel should be very proud of their efforts.

urn:contentItem:5W49-FTD1-JD34-V199-00000-00Planned burn near Harrow on Friday2019-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisPlanned burn near Harrow on FridayAlexander Darling

Forest Fire Management Victoria will seek to protect the residents and properties of Harrow on Friday, when it carries out a planned burn on Coleraine-Edenhope Road.

The burn is taking place south east of the township, and is expected to take place between midday and 6pm.

The authority said residents may be affected by smoke.

It follows four planned burns taking place in Little Desert National Park on Thursday. More than 1600 hectares have been burnt around Elliots Track, East West track, Dahlenburg's Mill track and Mallee track.

"The objective of these internal break burns is to develop fuel reduced areas of sufficient width, about 200m and continuity to reduce the speed and intensity of bushfires," a spokesperson said.

The spokesperson said for more information on planned burns, residents could visit ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn.

urn:contentItem:5M38-4YJ1-F0J6-J1XM-00000-00Stawell readies for fire season2016-11-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisINSIDE FRONTPg. 2Stawell readies for fire seasonAnthony Piovesan

Pomonal hosted the 27th annual Grampians Fire Conference last week ahead of the upcoming bushfire season.

Up to 100 Forest Fire Management Victoria representatives attended the conference along with water authorities and members from CFA, Victoria Police and state government.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Russell Manning said teamwork between emergency management agencies and private landholders would be vital for the coming fire season.

"At the conference we had the opportunity to focus on how we are working together to plan and deliver fire management on public and private land to reduce the impact of fire to communities," Mr Manning said.

Traffic management, evacuation plans and changes in standard operating procedures, community recovery and resilience were discussed at the conference.

Fire management in popular tourist areas was also discussed.

The conference occurred as part of Fire Action Week.

urn:contentItem:4P89-SH60-TXN5-V33C-00000-00Forest fire experts visit coast1999-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Forest fire experts visit coastKIM TREASURE

Top officials from major American and Canadian forest and park agencies will be on the South Coast this weekend to gain an international perspective on fire management.

NSW State Forests fire management forester Brett Shields said the region was being showcased because of its strong history of cooperative fire management under the guidance of the Southern Regional Fire Association.

He said the delegates would be shown how NSW led the way in active fire prevention, using prescribed burning to give firefighters a better chance of containing wildfires.

"Some of the most experienced and professional fire managers in the State are based in the Southern Region and the prescribed burning program and fire-training is world-class," Mr Shields said.

The 10 firefighters who will be in Batemans Bay over the weekend are some of the most senior people in North America's forest agencies - United States Forest Service, US National Park Service, Canadian Bureau of Land Management, and Parks Canada.

urn:contentItem:5W3N-J8Y1-JD34-V28W-00000-00Fox baiting program begins2019-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisFox baiting program begins

Fox baiting has started in central Victoria with Forest Fire Management Victoria laying baits in a number of state forests.

Baits have been laid in the Bung Bong, Costerfield, Wellsford, Redcastle, Mount Hoogly and Wareek state forests.

The fox baiting program aims to reduce attacks on native animals and livestock.

FFMVic acting senior forest management and roading officer Joe Rogasch said the program focuses on boundaries between public and private land.

"The 1080 poison shelf-stable baits will be buried in bait stations according to Victorian Directions for Use of 1080 products and manufacturer's guidelines to reduce the risk of non-target species taking them," Mr Rogasch said.

Mr Rogasch said it was important nearby residents and landholders ensured their dogs and other pets were confined to their property during the baiting period.

"We urge pet owners to take note of the signs and keep dogs on leash or muzzled while in or near baited areas," he said.

urn:contentItem:5M97-BRR1-JD34-V1R1-00000-00Rainfall pushes burns forward2016-12-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Rainfall pushes burns forward

Heavy spring rain has pushed Forest Fire Management Victoria's planned burns program out towards the start of the fire danger period, with the final burn scheduled for Golden Square this afternoon.

But FFMV senior forest fire management officer Simon Brown said the delay would not have a "huge impact" on fuel loads in and around Bendigo.

"It's just more around the timing, normally by mid-November our planned burning program is normally sort of complete and this year obviously with the spring rainfalls that we've had it's pushed it out later into the season," he said.

Mr Brown said while the burning off program had reached its end, there were other means of reducing fuel loads going into the fire season.

"We've had huge fuel management programs [in place], in slashing programs and mechanical works," he said. "So although this will be our last planned burn as such, we'll be continuing slashing and other fuel reduction works."

urn:contentItem:5M79-KJB1-JD34-V45F-00000-00Firewood collection season ending2016-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Firewood collection season ending

THE collection of firewood on public land will be banned over summer, starting next Thursday, December 1.

Peter Kambouris from Forest Fire Management Victoria said it would be illegal for people to collect firewood on public land until the start of the autumn firewood collection season, which is due to begin March 1, 2017.

"Firewood collection may already have ceased in some parts of the state where supplies are exhausted or where rainfall or flooding has affected track conditions making collection unsafe," Mr Kambouris said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria staff will be patrolling parks, forests and reserves to ensure people comply with the rules.

Typical on-the-spot fines for those breaking the law are around $622 and for offences that go to court, a person may be liable for fines up to $7773, one year imprisonment or both.

To find the nearest firewood collection area or for more information and updates visit the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning website, a DELWP office or call 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5VV6-K4X1-JD34-V234-00000-00Planned burn at Little Desert near South Australian border2019-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:57:34ZLexisNexisPlanned burn at Little Desert near South Australian borderAlexander Darling

Forest Fire Management Victoria will burn 171 hectares of scrub on the East West Track Internal Break at Little Desert National Park on Tuesday.

A statement from the authority said the fuel reduction burn near Neuarpurr and Frances should be completed between 12pm and 6pm.

"The burn objective is to develop fuel reduced areas of sufficient width and continuity to reduce the speed and intensity of bushfires," the statement said.

The body said smoke may be visible from Little Desert during these hours, and people may be affected by smoke in surrounding areas.

It recommended people close their windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering, and if they experienced any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, a Nurse on call could be called on 1300 606 024.
